subject: Live Incident Response Investigation - Linux
instructions:
You've been assigned to remotely investigate a compromised Linux server as part of a live incident response scenario. The affected system has been imaged and all necessary forensic artifacts have been gathered. Your objective now is to investigate the scope of the compromise and identify any persistence mechanisms installed by the attacker.

Use your endpoint analysis skills to conduct the investigation and answer the questions below. Remember, many investigative commands will need to be run with sudo to return comprehensive results.

Challenge File:

  • ~/Desktop/SOC_Level_1/Endpoint_Security/Linux/Challenge/challenge.elf

To start the challenge, run sudo ./challenge.elf in a terminal window. Make sure to not close the program or window until after you've completed the challenge. However, you can temporarily minimize it. After running the executable, you can open additional terminal sessions to complete the investigation.

After completing the challenge, you can clean up and restore the system by terminating the challenge.elf process (Press Ctrl + C).

questions.question: Simulate the compromise by running sudo ./challenge.elf in a terminal window. Make sure to not close the program or window until after you've completed the challenge. However, you can temporarily minimize it. Enter "done" to continue.
What port is the malware listening on?
questions.hint: The sudo netstat command can be paired with several useful options to display network connections and listening ports (-l).

questions.question: What is the Process ID (PID) of the malware? This answer cannot be verified, but it's required for the next question(s).
questions.hint: The netstat command can be paired with several useful options to display network connections, listening ports, and their associated Process IDs (PIDs).

questions.question: What is the name of the binary or executable associated with the network listener?
What is the full path of the previously identified binary?
questions.hint: There are several ways to find the path. However, one way involves using the lsof command against the previously identified Process ID (PID).

questions.question: Run the ps command against the previously identified malicious Process ID (PID). What is the full command line invocation of this binary?
questions.hint: The -F argument can be used to view the output in full format.

questions.question: What is the SHA-256 hash value of the malware? This answer cannot be verified due to potential version differences; however, it's a useful exercise.
questions.hint: You might have noticed that the malware was deleted immediately upon executing! However, you can still query binaries and executables held open by active processes through a specific virtual filesystem.

questions.question: Extract all printable string characters from the binary. Review the results for any indicators such as risky objects, descriptions, comments, banners, or usage information. Based on these findings, what utility or program can you identify?
questions.hint: The strings command is your friend here.

questions.question: Examine the system-wide cron jobs configured on the local system. Identify any entries that may be malicious, indicating persistence mechanisms or continued compromise by the attacker. What IP address and port number is the cronjob configured to conenct back to? Answer format: IP:Port.
Use a service like crontab.guru to interpret the cron schedule. On which specific day of the week does this cron entry run?
Excellent work! Clean up and restore the system by terminating the challenge.elf process (Press Ctrl + C). Afterwards, enter "done" to continue.
